Q: Insert Dynamic files in sourcecode that will update before every build A:
  • Right click the project or a folder in that project.
  • Select Add > Existing Item... from the context menu.
  • Select a source file.
  • Click the down-arrow on the  Add     | V button.
  • Select: Add As Link.

Another option is to create a class library project (*.dll) with these standard items and to add it as a reference to other projects. This is what most developers do.

Q: How can I dynamically load and execute `/foo.py` if it contains relative imports? A:

You do not actually need to mess around with sys.path. The way you've created the spec means that the dynamic module already knows what its parent package should be (code), and therefore where to search for relative imports. So long as python knows how to find the package that a module has declared itself to be a part of, then everything will work. In your scenario this would be the package code, as you declared your module name to code.foo.

Below I've includes a brief demo showing a module using a relative import that imports from the "declared" package of the module, rather than the package it is in relative to its place in the file system.

./pkg/some_module.py

VALUE = 'value'

./for_dynamic_import.py

# Would be a root module based on where this file would be found relative to sys.path
# But is attempting to import as if it were a submodule of pkg
from .some_module import VALUE
assert VALUE == 'value'

./main.py

import importlib.util
import sys

path = './for_dynamic_import.py'
spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location('pkg.foo', path)
# NB. Nothing about the the module name needs to match the path
# In this case, the declared package is pkg, and declared module name is pkg.foo
# However, it is actually found in ./for_dynamic_import.py rather than ./pkg/foo.py
mod = importlib.util.module_from_spec(spec)
spec.loader.exec_module(mod)

assert mod.VALUE == 'value'
print(f'{mod.VALUE=!r}')  # prints mod.VALUE='value'
print(mod.__name__)       # prints pkg.foo
print(mod.__file__)       # prints /./for_dynamic_import.py
print(mod.__package__)    # prints pkg

# final steps to make this module importable by other modules
# make module available under its full name in sys.modules
sys.modules[mod.__name__] = mod
# add module as an attribute of its parent package
setattr(importlib.import_module(mod.__package__), mod.__name__.split('.')[-1], mod)

# the module can now be imported from other modules as if it were a part of `pkg`
from pkg import foo
import pkg.foo
assert pkg.foo is foo is mod  # imports all retrieved the same module object

Q: Unity URP Crash: ArgumentException: RenderTextureDesc graphicsFormat must be a supported GraphicsFormat (R32_SFloat) A:

From URP docs :

Depth as Color

Unity adds this render target to the G-buffer layout when you enable Native Render Passes, 
and the platform supports them. Unity renders depth as a color into this render target. 
This render target has the following purpose:

    1) Improves performance on Vulkan devices.
    2) Lets Unity get the depth buffer
    on platforms that use the Metal graphics API, which doesn’t allow fetching the depth 
from the DepthStencil buffer within the same render pass.

The format of this render target is GraphicsFormat.R32_SFloat.

This has to do with selecting Deferred and Deferred+ Rendering paths. At least it doesn't seem to be avoidable. I looked into the code and the only format they seem to generate is the R32_SFloat. Coupled by the fact that there's no mention of alternatives in the docs section above, I'd say, if your device does not use it, you can't use the URP's default Depth stuff. More info.
